message_1: What is the Floer homology of the pair of pants, i.e., the non-orientable surface of genus one with three boundary components, in terms of the Floer homology of the circle?
message_2:
Floer homology is a powerful tool in symplectic geometry and low-dimensional topology, but it is not directly applicable to the pair of pants as you described it. The pair of pants you mentioned is a non-orientable surface, while Floer homology is typically defined for Lagrangian submanifolds in symplectic manifolds, which are orientable.

However, if you consider the orientable version of the pair of pants (i.e., a surface of genus 0 with three boundary components), you can relate it to the Floer homology of the circle. In this case, the pair of pants can be obtained by gluing three copies of the annulus along their boundary circles. The Floer homology of the circle is trivial, as it is a 1-dimensional manifold, and its Floer homology groups are zero in all degrees except for the zeroth degree, where it is isomorphic to the ground field.

When considering the orientable pair of pants, the Floer homology is not directly applicable, as it is a topological invariant rather than a geometric one. However, you can use Heegaard Floer homology, which is a related invariant for 3-manifolds, to study the pair of pants. In this case, the pair of pants can be viewed as a cobordism between three circles, and the Heegaard Floer homology of this cobordism can be computed. This computation is more involved and depends on the specific gluing maps used to construct the pair of pants.
